title: Beam Stress and Deflection Theory
content: Beam stress analysis involves calculating stresses and deflections in structural members under various loading conditions. The fundamental equations are based on Euler-Bernoulli beam theory, which assumes plane sections remain plane and material behavior is elastic.

title: Simply Supported Beam Analysis
content: A simply supported beam is supported at both ends with pinned connections that allow rotation but prevent translation. For a point load P at center of span L, maximum moment is PL/4 occurring at midspan, and maximum deflection is PL³/(48EI).

title: Cantilever Beam Analysis
content: A cantilever beam is fixed at one end and free at the other. This creates a statically determinate structure where the maximum moment occurs at the fixed support. For a point load P at the free end, maximum moment is PL and maximum deflection is PL³/(3EI).

title: Column Buckling Analysis
content: Column buckling is a sudden lateral deflection of a slender member under axial compression. The critical buckling load is given by Euler's formula: Pcr = π²EI/(KL)², where K is the effective length factor depending on end conditions.

title: Stress Concentration Effects
content: Stress concentrations occur at geometric discontinuities such as holes, notches, and fillets. The stress concentration factor Kt relates the maximum stress to the nominal stress. Sharp corners create higher stress concentrations than smooth transitions.

title: Mohr's Circle for Stress Analysis
content: Mohr's circle is a graphical method for analyzing the state of stress at a point. It provides a visual representation of how normal and shear stresses vary with orientation and helps determine principal stresses and maximum shear stress.

title: Fatigue Analysis and S-N Curves
content: Fatigue failure occurs under repeated loading at stress levels below the material's ultimate strength. S-N curves show the relationship between stress amplitude and number of cycles to failure. The endurance limit is the stress below which fatigue failure theoretically will not occur.

title: Mechanical Vibration Analysis
content: Mechanical vibrations involve oscillatory motion about an equilibrium position. Natural frequency depends on system mass and stiffness (fn = 1/(2π)√(k/m)). Resonance occurs when forcing frequency matches natural frequency, potentially causing large amplitudes.

title: Bearing Load Analysis and Selection
content: Bearings support rotating shafts and must be selected based on load capacity, speed, and life requirements. Ball bearings handle moderate radial and thrust loads, while roller bearings handle higher radial loads. Load life relationship follows L10 = (C/P)^p where p=3 for ball bearings.
